title: scsplit
description: scsplit is a genotype-free demultiplexing methode of pooled single-cell RNA-seq, using a hidden state model for identifying genetically distinct samples within a mixed population.

num.description: Type: `integer`. expected number of mixed samples
num.help_text: Type: `integer`. expected number of mixed samples

sub.description: Type: `integer`, default: `10`. maximum number of subpopulations in autodetect mode
sub.help_text: Type: `integer`, default: `10`. maximum number of subpopulations in autodetect mode

ems.description: Type: `integer`, default: `30`. number of EM repeats to avoid local maximum
ems.help_text: Type: `integer`, default: `30`. number of EM repeats to avoid local maximum

dbl.help_text: Type: `double`. correction for doublets. There will be no refinement on the results if this optional parameter is not specified or specified percentage is less than doublet rates detected during the run.

vcf_known.description: Type: `file`. known individual genotypes to limit distinguishing variants to available variants, so that users do not need to redo genotyping on selected variants, otherwise any variants could be selected as distinguishing variants
vcf_known.help_text: Type: `file`. known individual genotypes to limit distinguishing variants to available variants, so that users do not need to redo genotyping on selected variants, otherwise any variants could be selected as distinguishing variants.

geno.description: Type: `boolean_true`, default: `false`. generate sample genotypes based on the split result
geno.help_text: Type: `boolean_true`, default: `false`. generate sample genotypes based on the split result.

publish_dir.help_text: Type: `string`, required, example: `output/`. Path to an output directory.

param_list.description: Type: `string`, example: `my_params.yaml`. Allows inputting multiple parameter sets to initialise a Nextflow channel
param_list.help_text:
Type: `string`, example: `my_params.yaml`. Allows inputting multiple parameter sets to initialise a Nextflow channel. A `param_list` can either be a list of maps, a csv file, a json file, a yaml file, or simply a yaml blob.

* A list of maps (as-is) where the keys of each map corresponds to the arguments of the pipeline. Example: in a `nextflow.config` file: `param_list: [ ['id': 'foo', 'input': 'foo.txt'], ['id': 'bar', 'input': 'bar.txt'] ]`.
* A csv file should have column names which correspond to the different arguments of this pipeline. Example: `--param_list data.csv` with columns `id,input`.
* A json or a yaml file should be a list of maps, each of which has keys corresponding to the arguments of the pipeline. Example: `--param_list data.json` with contents `[ {'id': 'foo', 'input': 'foo.txt'}, {'id': 'bar', 'input': 'bar.txt'} ]`.
* A yaml blob can also be passed directly as a string. Example: `--param_list "[ {'id': 'foo', 'input': 'foo.txt'}, {'id': 'bar', 'input': 'bar.txt'} ]"`.

When passing a csv, json or yaml file, relative path names are relativized to the location of the parameter file. No relativation is performed when `param_list` is a list of maps (as-is) or a yaml blob.
